awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Haptic Glove for Real-Time Speech Comprehension
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project provides new tools to the deaf and hard-of-hearing populations.  Over 466 million people in the world with have hearing loss. This project will advance a technology to convert speech and other sounds in the environment to information that can be comprehended through the sense of touch. It has the potential to supplement existing techniques such as lip-reading and serve as a non-invasive, cheaper alternative to interventions like cochlear implant surgery.  Moreover, the research conducted herein will lay the groundwork for future devices leveraging touch-based communication, such as a wearable that converts digital input to touch-based information. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a way of converting auditory speech to information that can be perceived through the skin. The key research objectives include 1) the development of a touch-based language that intuitively represents words, similar to Braille; and 2) the development of a computerized glove that converts auditory input to the coded touch-based language and transmits it to the skin. This project will develop a mathematical formula to facilitate the efficient translation of auditory information into touch-based signals, and conduct research aimed at maximizing the discriminability of auditory signals perceived via touch. This will be used to guide electrode placement in glove development for sending signals to the skin. The anticipated results are the development of a basic prototype capable of converting speech to touch.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objectives of the project were the development of a haptic language that could efficiently convey complex information through the skin and the development of a wearable system that could translate auditory speech to this language and deliver it to the end user.

We pursued two approaches in our first objective of haptic language development, for our somatogram system. The first was based on real-time discrete wavelet processing of audio input information, like that used in cutting-edge cochlear implant devices.

As an alternative approach for the haptic language, we developed a system that was designed to form the basis of a vectorized system of mapping language to space. Here a computer algorithm generated path finding events, where rudimentary ideas or concepts can be conveyed by the shape and time-course traced by the stimuli locations. Here we focused on translation directly from text-based input, as this reduced problems associated with recording and interpreting sounds in varying environments.

Toward our secondary goal of hardware solutions for the delivery of these stimulation patterns to the skin, we created devices with a glove form factor and are working towards a forearm form factor. Fingers are more sensitive and have greater spatial resolution between point discrimination; however, in use, a commercial product on the fingers interferes to a greater extent with daily life. On the forearm, greater stimulation intensities had to be used, which could potentially be more painful and point-to-point discrimination is greatly reduced. One manner in which we addressed this trade-off was in development of physical pressure prototypes; in which we use vibration motors, and or specialized materials that change shape in response to charge and temperature. However, these proved slow, or bulky, and relatively expensive and so we doubled down on our efforts to refine our electrical stimulation approach.

Within the development of the electrotactile electrode system we experimented with stimulation intensity, duration, pulse shape, polarity and other factors. Electricity can drive vibration-like sensations on the skin, but it needs to be properly tuned and adjusted for the user, on that particular piece of skin (different parts of skin have different electrical properties and sensitivities).  Not only that, but stimulation intensity must be continually monitored and adjusted as skin conductance for the same user can change during extended periods of use. During our award period, we produced a stimulation microcontroller and the associated electrical hardware to drive the electrical pulses. Though a prototype these devices were miniature enough to be worn by a user, and capable of driving electrical patterns on stimulation arrays. We also created stimulation arrays for interaction with the users? skin (sets of 8x8 electrode arrays, of which several would be incorporated into a single wearable device, enabling stimulation patterns of up to 192 electrodes in a single glove or sleeve). We are currently pursuing bi-polar stimulation with more complex waveforms; the trade-off encountered here is that more that these advanced stimulation approaches require more hardware and space and border on making it too bulky and thereby non-portable.  Finding a balance between stimuli needs and minimum number of additional hardware remains a priority.
